newsitem.title: ARGENTINA: YPF says preliminary deal with Ecuador on Maxus.
newsitem.headline: YPF says preliminary deal with Ecuador on Maxus.

text.p: Argentina's YPF SA said Friday it had reached a preliminary agreement with Petroecuador which "unblocks the existing situation" over the operations of its Maxus subsidiary in Ecuador.

YPF said in a statement: "Today a preliminary agreement was reached between Petroecuador and the contractors of Block 16 -- situated in Ecuador's Amazon region -- of which YPF-Maxus is the majority partner and operator.
"This accord unblocks the existing situation and puts into action a negotiation mechanism with the object of changing the present services contract into a joint-venture contract."
"The contractors and Petroecuador commit themselves to agree the terms and conditions of the new accord in a maximum of 30 days," YPF said.

Ecuador's government announced late Tuesday that it was banning Maxus from continuing its operations in Ecuador until it reaches a joint-venture deal to share production with state-owned Petroecuador.

YPF added that it expressed to Ecuador's Mines and Energy Minister Alfredo Adum "its will to negotiate and the desire that the best solutions benefitting all interested parties be achieved without confrontation."
YPF, which has bought the Dallas-based Maxus, Wednesday said its subsidiary's facilities in Ecuador were producing normally despite the Ecuadoran decision.
Ecuador's government said that it was revising all oil contracts with foreign companies.
Late Thursday Petroecuador announced it had reached a preliminary deal with Maxus, but a Maxus spokesman in Dallas said talk of a solution to the problem was "premature".
